context: Jesus said to him, I do not say to you, up to seven times, but up to seventy times seven. That's actually 490, not 77. However Jesus' point wasn't the actual number, but that we not count the times we should forgive one another.
Seventy Times Seven is a profound gift: a nonfiction account of a costly act of forgiveness and a mustard seed of faith that miraculously moved mountains.

Christ referred to this 490 year probationary period when Peter asked Him if he should forgive his brother "seven times." Yet, #Christ said "seventy times seven" [490]. For Christ, as one with His Father, gave His brethren, the Jews, a 490 year window of forgiveness to repent.

Jesus speaks of forgiveness beyond what anyone had ever considered before: seventy times seven! Many commentaries understand this to mean that Jesus was telling Peter that he should forgive his brother a limitless number of times.

Some trivia for your #ComeFollowMe discussions: the number of times Jesus says we should forgive in Matt 18:22 is likely seventy-seven, not "seventy times seven" as the KJV puts it. Of course, if we're overly concerned about particular numbers here, we're missing Jesus's point!
Christ tells us to infinitely forgive those who wrong us. Seventy times seven is an expression representing an infinite sum.
To err is human, to forgive, divine. We are commanded to forgive 'seventy times seven', but that applies when remorse or repentance is offered.

The New English Translation (NET) is one of the few that gets the literal reference Jesus made of forgiveness with "seventy times seven" right. It is not 70 x 7 = 490. The expression is forgive 70 times, then add another 7 to it, which is more like 77. But the meaning remains.
